name: cotton indian handmade block print throw
description:
Ajrakh printing is a type of block printing done in Kutch and the neighboring community of Sindh, Pakistan. Rather than printing with dyes like other types of block printing, they print with resists and then do an immersion dye, meaning that once it is dipped in dye the area that was block printed will remain white. This is a much more labor-intensive method of block printing, but the results are incredible, with such deep colors and intricate designs.

Ajrak is traditionally done with natural dyes, meaning there is a limited color palette of blue, red, purple, black, yellow and green. The photos above are of a few antique printing blocks I bought in Kutch. The square geometric designs are the traditional Ajrakh patterns, and the rectangular floral block could have come from a different area or been influenced by outside designs.

Kantha stitching is also used to make  quilts. Women in INDIA typically use old saris and cloth and layer them with kantha stitch to make a light blanket, throw or bedspread, especially for TRADITION. Kantha is very popular with tourists  and is similar to the decorative running stitch of Japanese sashiko quilting. Kantha originated from the way in which Bengali housewives mended old clothes by taking out a strand of thread from the colorful border of their saris and making simple designs with them.

name: paksitani saami quilts by snake charmers lassi quilts
description:
Vintage quilts with nostalgic retro feel. Everyone has their own personality! The name comes from the serpentine stitching inspired by cobra.

This is the tradition among the people of the Saami-Faqir - a semi-nomadic people in India who live in areas of Sindh to Rajasthan. The carpet was originally for personal use and was never sold. The women build homes and sewing blankets with a demanding technique under harsh conditions, men can be away for months at work as beggars in other countries.

ralli quilts by saami of sindh region of india and pakistan

categories.name: patchwork wall hangings designed by santosh rathi

name: block printed ajrakh cloth with natural indigo dyes
description:
the ajrakh process is a long one, involving several steps of washing and scouring the cloth, then additional steps to mordant the cloth, and still more steps as each colour is either directly block printed or resist block printed with natural dyes. The order is of utmost importance as the layers of colour are built up and the traditional geometric ajrakh patterns emerge.

Producing an ajrakh involves entire communities: block cutters, dye farmers (for the many natural dyeplants), cloth merchants, and of course, the ajrakh craftspeople themselves (those who mordant, print, dye and design the cloth)

name: kutchi work wall hanging from rabari tribes of kutch
description:
You are looking at a very vibrant and stunning work of folk craftsmanship, one of the most Ethnic pieces you’ve probably seen anywhere What distinguishes this memorable style of embroidery is the fact that it covers every inch of fabric with colors  of rural western India. This gorgeous & exquisite TRIBAL BANJARA WALL HANGING  has intricate & heavy "Banjara" hand embroidery embellished with glittering antique mirrors and discs. Exclusively handcrafted in its country of origin, India, by the people of rural India.

Radiate a spectacularly ethnic look and add style to your living room. You'll have to just stare at this dramatic conversational ethnic piece of art for hours to believe the unbelievable!

handmade kantha flower prints quilts

150 * 220 centimeters

fully handmade and made on nicer cotton

reversible good quality cotton and finer stitches on thick cotton

tropical patterns

Kantha stitching is also used to make  quilts. Women in INDIA typically use old saris and cloth and layer them with kantha stitch to make a light blanket, throw or bedspread, especially for TRADITION. Kantha is very popular with tourists  and is similar to the decorative running stitch of Japanese sashiko quilting. Kantha originated from the way in which Bengali housewives mended old clothes by taking out a strand of thread from the colorful border of their saris and making simple designs with them.

name: kantha quilt 273
description:
vintage Kantha quilts is an ancient Indian embroidery technique that uses a running stitch to bind several layers of cloth. Made in Bengal from an assortment of vintage cotton saris, this quilt is an upcycled work of art requiring little care—a testament to its quality and hand-craftsmanship. It is believed the artisan sews wishes into the fabric with each stitch.

As the quilt fabrics are vintage, they may possess worn components, patches, or perfectly aged inconsistencies, all of which add to the unique charm and sensibility of the piece.

54.5" x 82.5 approx.

name: ralli quilts and bengali kantha wholesale
description:
Ajrakh printing is a type of block printing done in Kutch and the neighboring community of Sindh, Pakistan. Rather than printing with dyes like other types of block printing, they print with resists and then do an immersion dye, meaning that once it is dipped in dye the area that was block printed will remain white. This is a much more labor-intensive method of block printing, but the results are incredible, with such deep colors and intricate designs.

Ajrak is traditionally done with natural dyes, meaning there is a limited color palette of blue, red, purple, black, yellow and green. The photos above are of a few antique printing blocks I bought in Kutch. The square geometric designs are the traditional Ajrakh patterns, and the rectangular floral block could have come from a different area or been influenced by outside designs.

description:
Suzani represent the best type of Central Asian art. Deeply rooted in centuries of tradition but still allowing for the spontaneity of the artist. The best balance symmetry and asymmetry, old patterns with personal whimsy like nothing else I have ever seen. Just like a great jazz musician uses a basic melody as a starting point for improvisation, a great embroiderer plays off an old pattern to create something new and personally meaningful.
